Cherries and its effects on breast cancer

Summary generated using: $shovel3 query.concatConclusions 'breast cancer cherries site:ncbi.nlm.nih.gov' 40 includeReference=True
  • Having access to the story topics search facility clearly had the most positive effect on patient satisfaction and search success.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
      • title: How Breast Cancer Patients Want to Search for and Retrieve Information From Stories of Other Patients on the Internet: an Online Randomized Controlled Experiment
      • date: Jan-Mar 2010
      • authors: Regina Overberg, Wilma Otten, Andries de Man, Pieter Toussaint, Judith Westenbrink, Bertie Zwetsloot-Schonk
      • issue: 1
      • volume: 12
      • journal title: Journal of Medical Internet Research
      • abstract html url: /pmc/articles/PMC2855205/?report=abstract
      • doi: 10.2196/jmir.1215
      • pmid: 20215101
  • We found that posters felt they received more benefits from online communities than lurkers did, including emotional support, helping other patients, and expressing their emotions. Yet even lurkers were found to gain a certain amount of peer support through online communities, especially with regard to advice and insight/universality. The results demonstrate that participation in online communities—even as a lurker—may be beneficial to breast cancer patients’ mental health.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
      • title: Benefits of Peer Support in Online Japanese Breast Cancer Communities: Differences Between Lurkers and Posters
      • date: Oct-Dec 2011
      • authors: Yoko Setoyama, Yoshihiko Yamazaki, Kazuhiro Namayama
      • issue: 4
      • volume: 13
      • journal title: Journal of Medical Internet Research
